title: Radio, "Tykho", 1997
provenance: late 1990s: Max Pine; 2013: acquired by Museum
description: Block-like, rectangular yellow silicone rubber-covered body with short cylindrical dark gray antenna top right; face with circular speaker on left; volume and AM/FM buttons on right. Antenna rotates to act as tuner.
justification: Marc Berthier’s Tykho radio for Lexon has been noted in the mainstream and design presses—and the consumer electronics marketplace—since its introduction in 1997. That year, and recently—perhaps due to its fifteen-year anniversary—it has appeared in “Top Ten” design lists in US magazines and newspapers. In 2000, Time magazine featured the radio on its March 20th cover, sitting in a round glass bowl filled with a few inches of water, above the headline, “The Rebirth of Design.” Below the image, the text read: “Function is out. Form is in. From radios to cars to toothbrushes, America is bowled over by style.” The reappearance of the Tykho radio across blogs and magazines in the last few years shows the design’s lasting impact. The Tykho’s small, simple, monochromatic block-like form takes minimalism to an extreme.  The water and shock resistant body is ABS plastic covered by a smooth injection-molded, nearly seamless, silicon rubber shell.  It's radio functions are pared down to a bare minimum—no programmable channels, no earphone jack, no lighted dials or displays, no handle. Tuning is achieved by rotating the short antenna on the top right. The composition of the radio’s functions and controls is organized and clear: the form is divided into quadrants, the left dominated by the outline of a large circular speaker, the right containing small button-like volume and tuning controls. All these elements are center-aligned giving a visual balance to the radio’s face.  Berthier’s visual and tactile cues for the user carry through to the design of the skin-like silicon rubber buttons, making the AM/FM switch two separate raised disks and the volume control a linked button, a subtle reminder that the former are distinct functions while the latter represents two ends of a range. The sleek severity of the Tykho radio’s form is relieved by the intense candy-like colors in which Lexon produced the radio, including red, blue, yellow, white, and brown, that also serve as a reminder that the radio is ultimately a form of entertainment. http://www.lexon-design.com/la42r8-tykho-radio-red.html http://www.lexon-design.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/POMPIDOU-02.jpg http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,20000320,00.html Lindwell, William, and Manacsa, Gerry. Decontructing Product Design: Exploring the Form, Function, Useability, and Commercial Success of 100 Amazing Products. Beverly, MA: Rockport Publishers, Inc., 2009. pp. 198-199.

tombstone.epitaph: Radio, "Tykho", 1997. Silicon rubber, ABS plastic. Gift of Max Pine. 2013-6-1.
